string-array.name: not_your_fault_messages
string-array.item: Whatever happened was not your fault. No one has the right to sexually violate you. The rapist is solely to blame. What a person wears, what a person says, or how a person acts cannot justify sexual violence.
Most people are raped by people they know. You do not have to protect the perpetrator. Make protecting yourself your priority.
If you want to report the crime to the police, do so. Reporting sexual violence may help protect others from that person — may help you recover and heal from the incident

string-array.name: seek_medical_care_messages
string-array.item: You should seek medication care as soon as possible. 40% of rape survivors develop sexually transmitted infections as a result of sexual assault.

You should get medical attention right away without changing your clothes, showering, douching, or washing. Although it is a natural instinct to wash away all traces of a sexual assault, being examined right away is the best way to ensure you get proper medical treatment.

Immediate medical attention helps when people decide to report the crime, providing evidence needed to prosecute the rapist if a criminal case is pursued. If you have been raped and think you do not want to report it, you could report it later and having the medical exam results can help you.

Even if you do not get examined right away, you can still get a checkup later. It is always best to see a doctor immediately after a rape. But a person can still go to a doctor or local clinic to get checked out for STIs, pregnancy, or injuries any time after being raped.
All doctors and nurses will deal with your medical needs confidentially, and they will not inform anyone without your consent

string-array.name: signs_of_sgbv
string-array.item: Beware of torn, stained, or bloody underclothing as one of a physical sign of sexual violence
Beware of pain or itching in genital area as one of a physical sign of sexual violence
Beware of difficulty walking or sitting as one of a physical sign of sexual violence
Beware of bruises or bleeding in genital areas as one of a physical sign of sexual violence
Beware of frequent urinary or yeast infections as one of a physical sign of sexual violence
Beware of sexually transmitted diseases as one of a physical sign of sexual violence
Chronic depression as a behavioral symptom is far more common than physical ones
Pain or itching in genital area is a sign of sexual violence
The survivor might have difficulty walking or sitting
The Bruises or bleeding in genital areas is a sign of sexual violence
Beware of frequent urinary or yeast infections
Beware of Sexually transmitted diseases after sexual violence

string-array.name: home_contact_info
string-array.item: Whatever happened was not your fault. No one has the right to sexually violate you. The rapist is solely to blame. What a person wears, what a person says, or how a person acts cannot justify sexual violence.
Most people are raped by people they know. You do not have to protect the perpetrator. Make protecting yourself your priority.
If you want to report the crime to the police, do so. Reporting sexual violence may help protect others from that person — may help you recover and heal from the incident
You should seek medication care as soon as possible. 40% of rape survivors develop sexually transmitted infections as a result of sexual assault.

You should get medical attention right away without changing your clothes, showering, douching, or washing. Although it is a natural instinct to wash away all traces of a sexual assault, being examined right away is the best way to ensure you get proper medical treatment.

Immediate medical attention helps when people decide to report the crime, providing evidence needed to prosecute the rapist if a criminal case is pursued. If you have been raped and think you do not want to report it, you could report it later and having the medical exam results can help you.

Even if you do not get examined right away, you can still get a checkup later. It is always best to see a doctor immediately after a rape. But a person can still go to a doctor or local clinic to get checked out for STIs, pregnancy, or injuries any time after being raped.
All doctors and nurses will deal with your medical needs confidentially, and they will not inform anyone without your consent

resources.string: Messages to encourage the survivor or friend to report an incident - Programme team
Did the incident happen to you?
Safepal needs permission to use this feature. You can grant them in app settings.

string-array.name: wsgh_someone_else_array
string-array.item: How are you related to her/him?

resources.string: Are you a Man or Woman?
Tell the story of the incident.
Is this person female or male?
Is she/he a Man or Woman?
Tell the story of the incident.

string-array.name: apif_incident_type_below
string-array.item: What happened to him or her?
Someone tried to defile him or her

string-array.name: apif_incident_type_above
string-array.item: What happened to him or her?
Someone tried to rape him or her

resources.string: Thank you for submitting the Incident. The incident was successfully delivered to SafePal. \nSafePal will in a short while provide you with a person to assist you.
We have located the nearest ... (CSO) to you.\nThe people at this CSO have already gotten information about this incident and they will be contacting you soon.\nBelow are the details of this CSO.
Would you like to contact you?
Please enter a correct phone number
Get familiar with important information by viewing the quick help information below. Swipe left or right to show other information
No internet connection. Make sure Wi-Fi or cellular data is turned on, then try again
Click on the right bottom button to report a sexual violence incident directly to safepal and get linked to the nearest service provider for help.
If you are suspicious that perpetrator knows you are reporting him/her, use the left bottom \'Exit\' button to exit the safepal app or quickly uninstall it by long pressing on the \'Exit\' button.
\"Learning never ends\" - the saying goes, swipe left or right to get more information about sexual violence. Together, we can fight gender based violence
Does the victim have any disability
Talk to us if you or someone you know has been sexually assaulted
